00022 /*
00023  * Range lock is used to allow multiple threads writing a single shared
00024  * file given each thread is writing to a non-overlapping portion of the
00025  * file.
00026  *
00027  * Refer to the possible upstream kernel version of range lock by
00028  * Jan Kara <jack@suse.cz>: https://lkml.org/lkml/2013/1/31/480
00029  *
00030  * This file could later replaced by the upstream kernel version.
00031  */
00032 /*
00033  * Author: Prakash Surya <surya1@llnl.gov>
00034  * Author: Bobi Jam <bobijam.xu@intel.com>
00035  */
00036 #ifndef _RANGE_LOCK_H
00037 #define _RANGE_LOCK_H
00038 
00039 #include <libcfs/libcfs.h>
00040 #include <interval_tree.h>
00041 
00042 #define RL_FMT "["LPU64", "LPU64"]"
00043 #define RL_PARA(range)                          \
00044         (range)->rl_node.in_extent.start,       \
00045         (range)->rl_node.in_extent.end
00046 
00047 struct range_lock {
00048         struct interval_node    rl_node;
00052         struct task_struct      *rl_task;
00056         struct list_head        rl_next_lock;
00060         unsigned int            rl_lock_count;
00064         unsigned int            rl_blocking_ranges;
00069         __u64                   rl_sequence;
00070 };
00071 
00072 static inline struct range_lock *node2rangelock(const struct interval_node *n)
00073 {
00074         return container_of(n, struct range_lock, rl_node);
00075 }
00076 
00077 struct range_lock_tree {
00078         struct interval_node    *rlt_root;
00079         spinlock_t               rlt_lock;
00080         __u64                    rlt_sequence;
00081 };
00082 
00083 void range_lock_tree_init(struct range_lock_tree *tree);
00084 void range_lock_init(struct range_lock *lock, __u64 start, __u64 end);
00085 int  range_lock(struct range_lock_tree *tree, struct range_lock *lock);
00086 void range_unlock(struct range_lock_tree *tree, struct range_lock *lock);
00087 #endif
